title: Biblical Timeline
bibleVersions: en CSB-1713 NIV-111 NET-107 ESV-59 HCSB-72
tip: TIP: Hold down the <0>Shift key for horizontal scrolling

welcome.title: WELCOME!
message_wTags: If you've stumbled here, I hope you find this tool useful in some way. It's meant to be a way to quickly see the effects of different assumptions and interprations on the broader timeline without having to repeatedly do meticulous hand calculations. Keep in mind, though, that this is an ongoing, work-in-progress, side project. If there are any options that are missing or inadequate, please let me know!
⬆︎ Click the NOTES button in the header to bring up notes about the timeline (assumptions, calculations, etc.) as well as detailed explanations regarding available options and their effects.
⬅︎ Open the left SIDE BAR for date calculation and timeline display options. There you can also find project details and contact information.
⬇︎ The Go to Event... menu provides a quick way to jump to any spot in the timeline.

howMade.title: Where Did All These Dates Come From?
description_wTags: Plotting Biblical dates can be tedious and difficult. First of all, there are just so many dates to keep track of, but moreso, everything is in relation to everything else. For example, to get the year Joseph was born: we see that it was 30 years prior to the 14-year period of feast and famine in Egypt ... which began 9 years prior to Jacob's arrival there ... which happened 17 years before his death ... which was 147 years after his birth ... which happened 60 years after Isaac's birth ... which was 100 years after Abraham's birth ... and on and on back to Adam which ultimately establishes all the dates on the calendar. Whew!

After trying to "check the math", so to speak, on one author's claims, I realized that a computer could do this stuff much easier than me, and being a web developer, I decided it would be a fun little project to take on. Very quickly I realized that there are a lot of opinions and assumptions out there regarding Biblical dates, and nothing is quite as clean and clear-cut as you might think. So I decided to just add that variability as options with the benefit of getting to see what the different assumptions do to the timeline in relation to everything else.

As stated above, every date on the calendar is ultimately calculated relationally from Adam all the way to the Crucifixion using just the Bible. Once all the Biblical dates are calculated, I then use the user setting for the Gregorian date of the Crucifixion to then calculate and add all of the Gregorian dates to all of the events. Also once this is done, I am able to add secular, Gregorian-only dates to the timeline as well.
<0><0> AM / CE — Using the toggle at the top of the page, you can switch between displaying the Hebrew dates: AM (anno mundi), or the Gregorian dates: CE (common era - BC/AD)

<0><0> $t(options.showSource.title) — On / Off — Turn this on to show pop-up tooltips for each event listing the Bible verses referenced as well as a plain-language explanation of how the engine placed the item onto the timeline. If you don't need it, these pop-ups can be pretty annoying, so I have it disabled by default.

inclusiveTime.title: Time and the Bible: Inclusive vs. Exclusive
description_wTags: It is important to understand that the Bible uses an inclusive reconing of time which can be foreign to our modern, Western, exclusive thinking.

To illustrate, imagine the birth of a baby; only a full year later would we say that that baby is one year old, i.e., they have been alive for (at least) one full year. However, in Ancient Isreal, as soon as they were born it would have been said that the baby was one, i.e., they were in their first year.

Applying this to a Biblical example, in Gen5:32 when we read, "Noah was 500 years old, and he fathered Shem, Ham, and Japheth," we must understand that it is meaning that he was "in his 500th year" even though we would recon him to be 499 years old by our exclusive thinking.
All of this is to say that if you aren't expecting the difference between inclusive and exlusive reconing of time, the timeline might seem weird or off to you.

On a related note, because this timeline was built primarily to plot out the history recorded in the Bible, using inclusive dating, this means that the secular events added using only Gregorian dates may also not act completely as you might expect. Nonetheless, I find that having other historical events on the timeline very helpful.

manuscript.title: Patriarch Ages: The Masoretic Text vs The Septuagint
description_wTags: The ages of Adam through Terah found in Gen5 & Gen11 differ between the Masoretic Text (MT), Hebrew scriptures dating to the 2nd century AD, and the Septuagint (LXX), the Greek translation of the scriptures dating back possibly to the 3rd century BC. And for those curious about it, I'm not event going to bother with the Samaritan Pentateuch which appears to have a lot of problems in this area.

It's important to note that, despite the preponderance of evidence, and by what I would consider a quirk of history, all English bible translations — even the most recent — are still using the ages found in the MT. I assume changing the dates at this point would probably raise too much ire and controversy, which is unfortunate.
<0><0> $t(options.manuscript.title):

<0>$t(options.manuscript.best)</0> — There are a whole host of factors indicating that the LXX should be trusted over the MT with regards to the patriarchal dates with a couple of minor exceptions. I have heavily referenced <1>the work of Henry B. Smith Jr. of the Associates of Biblical Research</1> on the topic, and this settings is based on his assertions which mostly follow the LXX, but make corrections in a couple of key places.
<0>$t(options.manuscript.septuagint)</0> — Strictly follow the partiarchal ages found in the Septuagint.
<0>$t(options.manuscript.masoretic)</0> — Strictly follow the partiarchal ages found in the Masoretic Text. Note that the MT excludes Kainan (son of Arphaxad and father of Shelah).

margins.title: Margin of Error
description_wTags: When constructing a Biblical timeline as I am doing here, there will be a margin of error on all of your dates. This is inescapable just from the fact that the Bible lists only the year and not the month or day for most events.

For example, Gen5 & Gen11 list the years each patriarch had their first child, but were those births at the beginning of each year, the end, or more likely, somewhere in the middle? Naturally, that places a ±6mo margin of error on all dates where only a year is given.

For practicality, all such dates are averaged — put into the middle of the year — and a ±6 month margin of error is added to a compounding number. Starting with Adam, by the time you get to Christ, you are looking at a swing of more than two decades on your dates. While this margin of error is hidden by default, it's important to remember that they are there and any impression of fine precision you might have is actually a bit of an illusion. Having said that, plus or minus a decade can still be very useful at the scale of millenia.

<0><0> $t(options.margins.title) — Show / Hide — Note that even though the Gregorian dates are still, in a way, subject to the compounding margin of error, those margins are not applied to or shown on secular, Gregorian-only dates on the timeline.

pyramids.title: Ancient Chronologies
description_wTags: The accepted mainstream dates for ancient Egypt propose some real logistical problems regarding the timing of the building of the Pyramids and Noah's Flood. British Egyptologist David Rohl's proposed New Chronology shifts these dates forward significantly.
<0><0> $t(options.pyramids.title):
<0>$t(options.pyramids.mainstream)</0> — Use the mainstream chronology for ancient Egypt.
<0>$t(options.pyramids.revised)</0> — Use David Rohl's New Chronology for ancient Egypt.

exileStart.title: The Start of the Exile
description_wTags: Did the Exile period start with the first deportation at the surrender of king Jehoiachin or did it start with the destruction of Solomon's temple? This is almost certainly tied to the first deporation, but here's the option if you want it!
<0><0> $t(options.exileStart.title):
<0>$t(options.exileStart.deportation)</0> — The Exile started with the first deportation into Babylon at the end of Jehoiachin's reign.
<0>$t(options.exileStart.temple)</0> — The Exile started with the destruction of Solomon's temple at the end of Zedekiah's reign.

decree.title: The Decree to Rebuild the Temple
description_wTags: In Dan9:24-27 we read about 7 "weeks" (7-year periods), which start with the issuing of the decree "to restore and rebuild Jerusalem." When did the decree take place?
<0><0> $t(options.decree.title):
<0>$t(options.decree.cyrus)</0> — 2Chr36:22-23 - King Cyrus issued a decree in his 1st year to rebuild the temple, which was the last year of the exile.
<0>$t(options.decree.darius)</0> — Ezra6:1-12 - King Darius issued a decree in his 2nd year to resume work on the temple.

<0>$t(options.decree.ezra)</0> — Ezra7:11-26 - King Artaxerxes issued a decree in his 7th year that allowed any Israelites to return to Jerusalem, financially supported the temple and supplies, provided tax examption, ensured support from officials, and allowed legal autonomy.
<0>$t(options.decree.nehemiah)</0> — Neh2:1-8 - King Artaxerxes grants Nehemiah's request to rebuild Jerusalem and its walls.

persia.title: Persian Kings
description_wTags: Mainstream archaeology places the fall of Babylon to the Medo-Persian empire at 539 BC. This date is firmly established thanks to detailed Babylonian astronomical records. A chronology built from these records gives associated dates for the various decrees associated with Daniel's 70 Weeks prophecy. French independent scholar and linguist Gerard Gertoux has proposed an alternative interpretation of the Babylonian records which includes co-regencies and overlapping reigns.
<0><0> $t(options.persia.title):
<0>$t(options.persia.mainstream)</0> — Use the mainstream chronology for Medo-Persia.
<0>$t(options.persia.revised)</0> — Use Gerard Gertoux's alternative chronology for Medo-Persia.

daniel69.title: Daniel 9:25 and the "Anointed One"
description_wTags: In Dan9:24-27 we read about 7 "weeks" (7-year periods), the first 69 of which end with "an Anointed One, the ruler." This is a reference to Jesus, but does this period end with the triumphal entry (when he arrived as King), at his Baptism (when he was anointed by the Holy Spirit), or at his birth (when he arrived on earth)?
<0><0> $t(options.daniel69.title):

<0>$t(options.daniel69.birth)</0> — A multitude of angels announced Jesus' birth to the shepherds; magi from the East travelled great distances after seeing signs in the heavens; Simeon and Anna recognized Jesus as the messiah at his purification offering in the temple when he was 40 days old; the Jewish people were expecting the arrival of the messiah around that time.
<0>$t(options.daniel69.baptism)</0> — Jesus became "the anointed one" when he was baptized. It is only after this that he begins his minisry as the messiah.

<0>$t(options.daniel69.death) — At the Triumphal Entry, Jesus arrived at Jerusalem and was received as messiah and king. Days later he fulfilled his primary purpose as messiah: his substitionary death on the cross.

shmita.title: Sabbath and Jubilee Years
description_wTags: Lev25 mandates the observation of a sabbath year (the shmita) with this seven-year cycle itself referred to as a shavua (often translanted as "weeks" in Dan9:24-27. Israel was commanded to observe a jubilee year after every 7th shmita — like a shmita, but with additional laws and observances. There are different interpretations as to when to begin the count of the shavu'im, whether the exile acted like a count reset or not, and when exactly to observe the jubilee year.
<0><0> $t(options.shmita.title):
<0>$t(options.shmita.creation)</0> — Shavu'im count begins at creation.
<0>$t(options.shmita.exodus) — Shavu'im count begins when the Exodus is complete.
<0>$t(options.shmita.entry)</0> — Shavu'im count begins when Joshua leads Israel into the promised land.
<0>$t(options.shmita.conquest)</0> — Shavu'im count begins at the end of the conquest of the promised land.
<0><0> $t(options.shmitaReset.label):
<0>ON / OFF</0> — When on, Shavu'im ends at the Exile and restarts when the Exile ends.
<0><0> $t(options.jubileeOverlap.label):
<0>ON / OFF</0> — When on, the Jubilee overlaps the final shmita in the cycle. When off, the Jubilee overlaps the first year of the next cycle.

birthYear.title: Jesus' Birth Year
description_wTags: There is debate regarding the year of Herod the Great's death, placing it sometime between 6 BC and 1 BC, which affects the age of Jesus at birth.
<0><0> $t(options.birthYear.title):
<0>$t(options.birthYear.optionLabels.0) - $t(options.birthYear.optionLabels.4)</0> — Luke states that Jesus' age at his baptism was "about 30", so double check his age as you fiddle with options.

ministryLength.title: The Length of Jesus' Ministry
description_wTags: There is a debate centering on John 6:4 as to how long Jesus' ministry lasted. Did it begin prior to Passover and end with his Crucifixion at the following Passover (a little more than a year), or did it end after a third Passover (a little more than two years)?
<0><0> $t(options.ministryLength.title):
<0>$t(options.ministryLength.two)</0> — Jesus' ministry lasted a little more than 1 year.
<0>$t(options.ministryLength.three)</0> — Jesus' ministry lasted a little more than 2 years.

crucifixion.title: Crucifixion Date
description_wTags: I have written at length about this here: <1>Analysis of the Timing of the Crucifixion</1>. Long story short, the data pointed me to 31 AD, which I use as the default here.
<0><0> $t(options.crucifixion.title):

<0>$t(options.crucifixion.optionLabels.0) - $t(options.crucifixion.optionLabels.2)</0> — Traditionally, the crucifixion is placed at 30 or 33 AD, I propose 31 AD. This option lets you place it in any year during Pontius Pilate's time in Judea (26-36 AD).

sojourning.title: Sojourning: Abraham to the Exodus
description_wTags: There can be a little bit of confusion about the time from Abraham to the Exodus. When was Abraham called by God? How long were the Israelites sojourning (as some translations put it) in Egypt? At first glance, it seems like there are three irreconcilable time periods: 400, 430, and 450 years, but with a little digging we can make some sense out of it.

Our first number, and the one where the translation you use can make a big difference, comes in Gen15:13 (and Acts7:6), "Know this for certain: Your offspring will be resident aliens for four hundred years in a land that does not belong to them and will be enslaved and oppressed."

Many translations read something like, "they will be enslaved for 400 years," which leaves little wiggle room. However, some translations, like the CSB above, do a little bit better job of capturing the parenthetical nature of "enslaved and opressed". We are being told that Abraham's offspring will be resident aliens for 400 years, and that, during some portion of that time, they will be enslaved and opressed. Much like someone who is told, "you will go to an all day event and will have lunch," wouldn't expect to be eating for 8 hours.

Instead of looking for the onset of the oppression and trying to start this 400 year period perhaps when Joseph gets sold into slavery in Egypt, or maybe some other nebulous time later, we should instead look for the moment when Abraham's offspring became resident aliens — which has an obvious and exact date in my opinion: Isaac was born as a resident alien, so his birth seems to be the best fit. If it weren't obvious enough from context, in Gen21 where we read about Isaac's birth, the Bible explicitely calls out in verse 23, almost as a reminder, that Abraham and his family were indeed resident aliens at that time.

Our next number comes from Acts13:17-20 which tells us that the time in Egypt + the time wandering the desert + the time taking the promised land took "about 450 years" (emphasis added). We can surmise through an examination through the book of Joshua that the taking of the land should be close to about seven years, which does fit within Paul's rounded "about 450" number and lines up well with our 400-year time period.

Finally, if we head over to NET|Exo12:40-41, we read that the time that the Israelite people were in Egypt was 430 years. This turns out to be problematic in a couple of different ways. Our first problem is that it presents a time in Egypt that is far longer than fits with the two dates we've already established.

To solve this, let's take a look at a couple of relavant passages in the new testament. In Gal3:16-17 Paul states that the law was given 430 years after the promise, and Acts7:2 reminds us that the promise was given while Abraham was still in Mesopotamia (Haran); the promise must have been given, at a minimum, 190 years prior to Joseph being taken into Egypt. In other words, the 430 years must include Abraham's time in Canaan. Indeed, when we go back and look at the Exodus verse in the Septuagint, we can see that it includes "...and in Canaan..." where the Masoretic Text does not.

With that problem solved, our second arises. Gen12:4 tells us that Abraham was 75 years old when he left Haran — 25 years before the birth of Isaac. What are we to do, then, with the extra 5 years that arises between "the promise" being 30 years prios to Isaac, but Isaac being born only 25 years after Abraham left Haran? There are a couple of ways that this can be resolved:
<0><0> $t(options.sojourn.title):

<0>$t(options.sojourn.early)</0> — This is the stronger option in my opinion. You can either read Gen12:1-4 as "God called Abraham out of Haran with a promise, and some time later Abraham left." which places the promise about five years prior to Abraham leaving Haran, or there is some Greek textual support for reading Acts7:4 such that Abraham left Haran prior to his father's death. Whether he left before his father died or waited a while after the promise has interesting theological implications (you could get a sermon out of either of those), the effect on the timeline either way is the same.

<0>$t(options.sojourn.late)</0> — If the Promise, Abraham's departure, and Haran's death were indeed all the same year, then you must push back the beginning of the 400 and 450 year periods to begin when Isaac was about 5 years old. Some have tried to argue that this has to do with higher infant mortality rates and that the Israelites wouldn't count a person until after their 4th or 5th year, but I personally am unable to find any independent support for that assertion.

version.title: Website Version History

• 2024-06-02

project.description: This project began in 2020 as a quickly hobbled together collection of PHP and CSS I threw together over a weekend just to visualize and verify some things I was reading about. Fast forward to 2024, where I have revisited the idea, but this time set out to build it properly — from the ground up, with modern web dev tools — into something that will hopefully be more usable for, not just me, but anyone who might find it useful!
project.description2_wTags: While I have included many options to accommodate differing views, interpretations, and sources, I doubt I have covered all scenarios. In other words, I am in no way claiming any sort of expertise on this topic ... but I'm also not claiming to come to this completely without opinion either. Mostly, though, I just wanted to do something with my development skills that might help someone else. Feel free to send me a message if you think there's something that could be improved or added, or if you are so inclined and able, the code for this project is available on Github for you to fork and tinker around with yourself.
project.cookies: Cookies are used for saving preferences only.

options.notificationText: For detailed information about these options, why they're here and what they do, please see the notes.

eventPicker.title: Events are Ordered by Start Date

nimrod.title: Nimrod [SPECULATION]
nimrod.source: NET|Gen10:6-12, Birth and age speculated based on ages of contemporaries

babel.title: Tower of Babel [SPECULATION]
babel.source: Gen10:25 and tradition places Peleg's birth around the same time as the Tower of Babel
babel.placement: A roughly 10-year span around the time Peleg was born

daniel.title: Daniel [SPECULATION]
daniel.placement: Daniel was a young man when taken to captivity, which would most likely put him at 13-20 at the time of the exile. We also know that he served

messiah.title: Jesus Christ
messiah.note: All CE dates are calculated from the set crucifixion date

pyramidsGiza.title: The Great Pyramids of Giza Built

persianEmpire.title: The Medo-Persian (Achaemenid) Empire
persianEmpire.note: Thanks to detailed astronomical records, this date is firmly established at 539 BC

cyrus.title: Reign of Cyrus the Great (over Babylon)
cyrus.note: This should align with the start of $t(events.persianEmpire.title) in 539 BC
